:ctwokinds-nibsdance::ctwokinds-nibsdance::ctwokinds-nibsdance:
:ctwokinds-nibsdance::ctwokinds-nibsdance::ctwokinds-nibsdance:
Before you go Tom, could you answer a question for me?
Yes.
There, answered.
What is you opinion on drawing tablets, screen or no screen?
lol
I would expect nothing less.
He appearith
Screen
I mean, I've used both. I started out on no screen for years.
Never try the ‚ÄúCan I ask you a question?‚Äù Thing with a smartalek
But screen is just fundimentally better.
Funds, though, is the key word.
Okay, cause I am looking into the market.
Yeah.
Wacum as a cool non-screen but Huron has a nice screen one for the same price.
has*
Huion*
derp.
I've never used a Huion. I've heard they're pretty good.
I imagine that anything I can get around a few hundred would be very good.
The cheapest Wacum is like 1500.
With a screen that is.
That is just too much of an investment when I am not very sure if this will go that far.
True, but you could always sell it off at a small loss.
But yeah. $1500 is insane.
Yeah, but I do not have $1500 laying around to spend.
I am excited though, by the end of August I should have a new computer, peripherals, a drawing tablet of some sort, a new desk, and chair.
I would imagine a $1500 tablet would be a full PC in itself.
The desk will be long so I can have my computer on it, the drawing tablet, and still have room to do paper work.
I do not know, I think they are just a peripheral.
Unless you get like a $5000 one.
Where the whole thing is a desk.
I do not know, I just ball parked that price for something like tphat.
that*
Ok they are full PCs but overpriced IMHO for what they are.
only 6th gen I7s, only 8GBs of RAM, and Intel Iris integrated graphics. (Not that you are going to game on a drawing tablet. lol)

God no, if anything I would just get a fancy monitor to hook up to my beast of a computer...uh...when I get a beast of a computer. But my new laptop I will be getting will not be that bad, and upgrade-able internals. XD Big plus.
Yeah cheapest thing Wacon sells with a screen is $1k for a 13" pen display
Yeah.
and only 1080p
That is why I asked Tom if a screen was worth it. Since it seems to be a big difference, and understandably so, I will be looking at other brands for affordable tablets with screens.
Makes sense. I would imagine a screen would be a must.
I couldn't imagine trying to draw looking up at a screen, and using a pad that was nothing but the input device.
Yeah, until someone recommended Huion to me, I was just settling on Wavum's Intuos Pro, which is their largest non-screen tablet.
Was it you who recommended Huion?
I cannot really remember.
Nope sorry, I don't draw.

In either case, I can see a screen be very helpful, but a non-screen tablet if affordable could be done. Just takes some practice and getting you muscle memory to a point where you can trust your hand to draw while you look at a separate screen.
being*
Right, I am sure people can get used to it, but it'd definitely have a learning curve.
Last I really tried drawing was in middle school, I would take VHS recordings of anime I watched on Toonami, and would freeze frame it on the TV, and I would draw the character.

Oh yeah. In my case I can kind of see what I am drawing in my head so I can overlay that onto what I am seeing my hand draw on the tablet if that makes any sense. All it would do is give me a starting place to learn.
Nice.
If I tried drawing on my own, I couldn't keep things int he proper scale. lol
maybe one day I will pick up drawing again. might interest me more to do it through digital means than using pen and paper.
Pencil and paper*

Ohh yeah, I get what you mean. I have not drawn in a long time and I have not drawn that match to begin with. However, in that time I did manage to produce some pretty good work so I feel with enough practice and sketch after sketch after sketch I can get
there.
Exactly, digital drawing really captures my interest far more than pencil and paper. Not that those are bad, they are just much harder to feel like you are making progress at all when practicing.
Plus, you can do so much more with a digital drawing than you can with a paper and pen one.
